both.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: used to talk about two people, things etc together, and emphasize that each is included
both.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: You can both swim, can’t you?
Oxford is not far from Stratford, so you can easily visit both in a day.
Both of my grandfathers are farmers.
both.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You use both before a plural noun
both.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: You use both or both of before a determiner such as ‘the’, ‘these’, or ‘my’
both.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You use both after a pronoun
both.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: You use both after the first auxiliary verb
They could both be described as robots
both.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: Both is not usually used in negative clauses You say
Neither of these methods is perfect
Both of these methods are not perfect
